title: Seven locals now tech billionaires after record high stocks
text:
Meanwhile Mr Cannon-Brookes and Mr Farquhar are set to be Australia's richest and second-richest people when the 2020 Rich List is published in 10 months' time, should the maker of collaboration software achieve even half of the 65 per cent share price gain it has achieved in the past 10 months.

The University Of NSW alumni are worth $14.2 billion and $13.4 billion respectively based on Friday's close of $US141.20 for Atlassian, which goes by the Nasdaq ticker of TEAM.

Atlassian's share price was supercharged in May when broker Goldman Sachs raised its rating on the stock to 'buy', opining that the ubiquity of its products among developer teams would enable it to maintain annual price increases, and that its "low-friction online sales motion" would allow it to keep penetrating non-IT organisations.

Mr Cannon-Brookes has leapfrogged Mr Farquhar, who was valued at $120 million more than him in the 2019 Rich List, because of an updated accounting for his investments in neo-bank Tyro and autonomous vehicle maker Zoox.

Zoox itself is the maker of another local tech billionaire in Tim Kentley-Klay, who was sacked as chief executive last year but retains a 25 per cent stake, which was valued at $4.5 billion by a $US500 million capital raising the month before his ouster.

The low risk-free rate which has been driving up equity markets has also spurred global venture capital markets. In May they valued Canva, the maker of intuitive graphic design software with 15 million active users, at $3.6 billion based on a $70 million injection from Silicon Valley's General Catalyst.

Canva co-founders (and recently engaged couple) Mr Obrecht and Ms Perkins were together valued at only $177 million by the 2018 Rich List. Their dramatically higher, $1.35 billion valuation today is based on a new understanding that they, alongside technical co-founder Cameron Adams and early staff given sweat equity, have retained more than a 50 per cent ownership in Canva despite seven rounds of external funding.
description: Near-record highs on the ASX 200 and Nasdaq have propelled a technology wealth boom, with Australia now home to seven billionaire individuals or couples.
